And he raised just a million dollars less than Senator Hilary Clinton and surpasses the other candidates besides Senator Clinton.

It's too soon.

Oh, not only puts the nail in it, it buries it about six to eight feet deep.
I mean, I think there are four significant things about what he achieved in this first quarter.
Number one, he is a neophyte compared to the rest of the field - we have to remember that.
Everyone else has much more experience, particularly at federal level, than Barack Obama.
Number two is the breadth of donors.
As Julianne even mentioned, 100,000 different people contributed, and no political action committee money.
Also, the conduit used.
He raised almost $7 million online.
And then there's a force that he's convened that I think not only speaks to his campaign, but sort of the next generation of black political leadership.
He, along with Deval Patrick and Cory Booker, when he ran for mayor of Newark, they're campaigning were really grassroots insurgencies.

They are bringing back retail politics in new clothing, in new technology, and I think it's fascinating that as black candidates that are using these new tools to gain an advantage in political campaigns.

I think so, but I think that what Walter and Julianne have both had said is absolutely correct.
The Obama movement is an insurgency.
If you look at the numbers as my colleagues just said - 100,000 donors.
Senator Obama got more donations, 50,000 off of the Internet, and Senator Clinton, for goodness sakes, only have 50,000 donors, period.
I think that he represents a new breath of fresh air in the leadership in our country.

And Senator Clinton's whole strategy thus far has been to take all the money and the excitement and the oxygen out to choke everybody else out of the system so that she would run to the finish line to win the nomination.
I think what we saw yesterday clearly indicates that Senator Obama has a groundswell of support.
He has the support of lower-income folks, of middle-income folks, of high-profile individuals, and he's going to be very difficult to stop as we move forward to the primary season later this year.

Oh, absolutely so.

You know, black children get targeted because they have attitude problems, when oftentimes white teenagers in particular just acting out.

Is this a situation where she was given an excessive sentence, or is this is a situation where media attention pressured officials into lessening a sentence that they shouldn't have?
Clearly, it was an excessive sentence, Farai.
I mean, not only rapists, murderers.
You can make a list of the people - robbers with guns.
This was a child.
Understand that this was a child who allegedly pushed a - we need to use the word allegedly here as well, because the reports of this have differed wildy.
Some people stay pushed, some people say touched - simply touched the woman.
So it definitely depends here.
But that was an excessive sentence that - she represents a tip of the iceberg.
How many others of our children are in juvenile detention for excessive periods of time who didn't have the NAACP or the media attention that this case has?
I think this really calls us for us to begin to look at what what's happening in K-12 education.
Remember just a couple of years ago that five-year-old girl who was handcuffed at school because she was having a tantrum?
Which 5-year-old has not had a tantrum?
Two police officers handcuffing a 5-year-old child.
So this isn't the first time it's happened.
The Shaft Foundation has looked at - based in Boston - looked at what happens with black boys in terms of things like suspensions and detentions.
And literally, most of the suspensions that occur inner city school are of our children, not of other children.
So our children are being victimized because some teachers and some of the teachers also happen to be African-American, but come in with attitudes and biases against these children.
These children are precious little resources.
They're our babies, and they need to be protected, not victimized.
Teenagers don't have whole brains.
I know my teenage sons get annoyed with me when I say they don't have whole brains.
Their brains are developing, so the child acts out is not unusual.
She should not be incarcerated for that, but instead counseled.
Ron, whose responsibility is it to keep watch over issues like how children are disciplined according to race?
Is this something that every individual school system needs to monitor?
Is this a city or a state issue?
Is this even a federal issue?
How do you begin to move forward if there are discrepancies?

Well, absolutely, I think that our school districts, our principals, our superintendents, our city councilmen and women and the mayors have a moral obligation to ensure that those children who are in the schools, the elementary school system, the high school system and their specific jurisdiction, they have a moral responsibility and an obligation to ensure that these children are in a safe environment where they can learn.
When you have teachers who allegedly are being pushed by students, young kids act out.
Young kids have temperate tantrums.

But if these children are being systematically chosen due to their race and given severe punishment, I think that's a breakdown in the system, a breakdown in the system of academia and our teachers need to be held accountable.

This case is so morally outrageous that this young girl was put away, and as Julianne said a few moments ago, when you have robbers, when you have people who have committed serious violent crimes who have been in jail less time than this young girl, there is a breakdown in the system that needs to be fixed.

has been dominant for so long, but China is making great moves politically and especially economically.
